value: Prætsø Fjord with the towns marina in the background

Small in size, but rich on history;
is a picturesque ancient merchant borough dating back to the 14th century, at the bottom of a small fjord of the same name. It makes for a worthwhile excursion if you're in the area.

The last train has long since made it's final trip to Præstø, so you'll either need your own wheels or jump on a bus, which is a fairly infrequent occurrence, so plan ahead. 

Buses
which has frequent train services to
. Another, more combersome option from the capital is Bus
which has train services on the
which is on the end of the
further south on the same railway line as Næstved, so use this if you are heading south towards the islands (Lolland-Faster). Line
is your choice for going onwards to

as it ends in Stege, the islands largest city. 

If you have your own wheels, simply follow the
motorway (E47/E55) to either exit 38 (Tappernøje) or exit 39 (Bårse) and turn east, it's well signposted - the former is the most picturesque as it will take you along the fjord.

value: directions=In the west end of town, take bus 79 to Rødeledvej Stop
content=This workshop and museum is the oldest pottery in Denmark.
directions=In the northwest end of town

content=Nysø is a beautiful old mansion from 1673, build as one the first baroque buildings in the country by a local merchant. Thorvaldsens small white atalier (see below) is still found in the park. Entrance to the building is summer only, and only to the museum wing.

content=One of Denmark's few blockbuster artists; sculptor Bertel Thorvaldsen (1770-1844) spent his final years here, and had a atelier provided by the baron and baroness. The collection, which is housed in one of the wings, includes many works from his time on Nysø Manor.

content=Locals are working to convert the now disused townhall into a cultural center. Thus far, the efforts have resulted in a exhibition of naturalistic landscape painting of the surrounding countryside by Ole Ring (1902-1972).
content=The local activity centre with theatre, temporary exhibits, concerts, cinema and a café
content=Three daily trips on the fjord between Feddet and Præstø in week 27 to 32. The route lives on yearly grants, so check ahead of it runs.
price=3 hours 300 Kr, full day 500 Kr
content=Canoe rentals for sailing in the fjord. Safe 530cm sink free canoes for up to three adults, rent includes life jackets and map
content= Horse riding with Icelandic horses also have an activity centre with peashooter and air-rifle shooting, archery and paint ball..
directions=leave Præstø and go south towards Møn on Mønvej. After 10 minutes you will see the labyrinth park on the right hand right next to the road
hours=Open all days during the summer holidays 10AM-6PM, rest of the year check for opening hours

content=Although the park is not big, it is quite interesting and you easily spend half a day there. They have labyrinths and large puzzels outside and a room indside with smaller puzzels and mind games. They sell sandwiches and ice cream, but also have a picnic area if you want to bring your own food.
Adelgade is the main shopping street

.  Almost all of the retail stores in the town is placed in the centre of town on Adelgade which runs east-west parallel to the seafront, one street up. This includes a music store, several fashion shops, sports equipment, combined optician, jewelery and watch shop, a delicatesse store, electric erquipment, household equipment etc.

.  The town has four grocery stores, Aldi (on Vesterbro as you enter the town from the west), SuperBest and Netto (both placed on Svend Gynges torv in the centre of town. Right next to the bus terminal) and Fakta (on Østerbro east of the town centre). Because of the close proximity to a harbour they are allowed to be open 7 days a week during the tourist season. SuperBest also houses a bakery with individual opening hours (opens early in the morning).
content=Combined café and restaurant with live music during summer. Seating both inside and outside right on the harbour front
content=Family type restaurant with a kids friendly menu placed in the center of town right off the main street in a small plaza
content=Vacation Centre in an old manor from 1850. Has teamed up with other local outfits to provide horse riding, canoeing and sailing as part of stays here.

content=Newly renovated Inn, some would argue a bit too thoroughly, with great views over the fjord, but a fair bit away from the town itself. Rooms with private patios to enjoy the view, and a camping ground (which seems to be full year layovers only though). There is a nice beach nearby,

content=Impeccably renovated "old world" hotel from 1870. Amazing views of over the fjord, B&O televisions in the rooms, paintings, hunting trophees and professional staff. The on-site restaurant serves fresh local produce, in a nice light conservatory with sea view.
content=Built in 1780, this intimate B&B in a white half timbered house with thatched roof, offers 'mini apartments' with kitchenettes and a small attached patio with table and chair.

(just by Frederiksminde Anlæg).
Address: Klosternakken 8.
Phone: +45 5590 9192

Only open during summer (22/6 - 21/8 for 2010)
Tue-fri: 10-16, Sat: 10-14, Sun-Mon: closed

Præstø is part of the Vordingborg municipality which offers a common tourist web site: http://www.visitvordingborg.dk
. The city post office is placed indside the SuperBest Grocery store. It is open mon-fri: 10.00-17.00.
offers free Internet connection as WiFi network.
Præstø is placed 20 minutes by car from

. Vordingborg and Næstved are larger cities with more shopping opportunities and an old center of town.
